This isn't anything to do with filing, you have to file taxes for your LLC regardless. This is about protecting yourself by separating--you from the business.
For example, you shoot a gig but your contract required X and instead you did Y. Now they take you to court for breach of contract and it's clear you breached the contract. Now you are jointly and severally liable for the awards the judge ruled for...you see what I'm saying.
Your going to file separate tax returns anyways, unless you took a Sub S Election (talk with your CPA) which you would be itemizing your taxes as a flow through entity. Regardless, this is about protecting you FROM your businesses liabilities.

When you purchase a home you transfer title of the property at the closing. Title is a legal term that means ownership. In property law the legal document that conveys title is called a deed. There are, usually, three types of deeds:
(1) Warranty Deed: The owner who you are purchasing from proclaims title is clear steaming from before they owned it and after they owned it. (Greatest protection)
(2) Special Warranty: Owner proclaims title is clear ONLY from the point they took title to you taking title, not before they took title.
(3) Quit Claim Deed: Owner proclaims NOTHING, just conveys title with no guarantee they even own the property.
When you get a bank financed loan they require you to have a Warranty deed conveyed to you. They require a warranty deed because that transfers the greatest protection on their investment. Remember both you and the bank are investing in the transaction. Now when you close on the house there are title insurance documents you sign; part of the closing cost goes to a title insurance company who verifies the title is clear.
Once you close, you are the owner of the property and have been conveyed title at the signing. What the bank does is files a lien on the property to perfect their interest in the amount you owe them. By protecting their interest they are putting all other potential lien holders on notice that they have a perfected security interest in the property and if any other lender wants to give you a loan and take your house as collateral they will have a junior lien to the banks senior lien. Sounds super complicated but it's not, it's just there for the banks to protect their interest if you were to file bankruptcy or failure to pay.
After you pay off the loan the bank should send you the original promissory note you signed with them, stamped canceled or paid, whatever their system is. The bank should also send you a mortgage release; this is the most important document--you should immediately go and have this recorded at the country registrar of deeds.
The records are recorded in chronological order. When you go to sell that home one day the title insurance company will review the record and see that you took out a lien on the property and X years later you have a stamped/ certified release of that lien. If you/the bank does not record the release it will show that you still have a lien on your property and the deal could fall through.
If you have any other questions consult a real estate attorney who will give you a free consultation.
